content: President takes questions from 13 reporters, including a French news agency, but skips America's top newspapers, including The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Washington Post and USA Today. What has created a bit of buzz both times was who was on the list -- and who wasn't. News organizations who got questions Tuesday included The Associated Press and all five major television outlets, plus Politico, the Spanish-language network Univision, the military's Stars and Stripes newspaper, Agence France-Presse, Ebony magazine, ABC Radio and The Washington Times, the only major newspaper on the list. "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/first100days/2009/03/25/questions-obama-skips-major-papers-news-conference/" ***I've listened to the Left bash Bush for selecting his audience. Is not Obama doing the same?*** "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
reply: President takes questions from 13 reporters, including a French news agency, but skips America's top newspapers, including The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Washington Post and USA Today. One of the biggest criticisms of President Bush was his tendency to screen the audience at his events. Not a good card carrying Republican and significant contributor to the party, you need not apply, unless you were in a uniform…then you’re part of the background.

content: Those reporters President Obama is calling on, many of which, used to be seated in a section of the press corps called "Siberia" by the Bush Administration, and were never-ever called on for questions. No wonder people are so surprised by the news reporters being called upon by President Obama. Fact is, plenty of main stream national news organization reporters were called upon, and some with very tough questions. I mean, how many President's have ever called on a reporter in a national news conference like the one was called on from "Stars and Stripes?" "I believe that banking institutions are more dangerous to our liberties than standing armies." - T. Jefferson

content: If the Democrats are concerned enough about the state of the newspaper industry to propose legislation to save them, isn't this counterproductive? Wouldn't it make more sense for the POTUS to call on the reporters from these struggling newspapers in order to give them more credibility? If the POTUS doesn't care enough about these newspapers to call on their reporters during a press conference, why should the American People care enough to buy their papers?
reply: If the Democrats are concerned enough about the state of the newspaper industry to propose legislation to save them, isn't this counterproductive? If the POTUS doesn't care enough about these newspapers to call on their reporters during a press conference, why should the American People care enough to buy their papers?
title: No Questions: Obama Skips Major Papers at News Conference

content: Papers have been struggling not so much due to lost revenue from subscriptions, but instead from lost advertising revenue. Credibility isn't what they are lacking, they are lacking the funds that sites such as Craigs List have impacted. Pay $500 or more to post a car ad in the paper or pay $0 for Craigs List.

content: quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: Papers have been struggling not so much due to lost revenue from subscriptions, but instead from lost advertising revenue. Credibility isn't what they are lacking, they are lacking the funds that sites such as Craigs List have impacted. Pay $500 or more to post a car ad in the paper or pay $0 for Craigs List. What questions Obama gave to the unknowns were on the internet that Al Gore created before the reporters even left the room.

title: No Questions: Obama Skips Major Papers at News Conference

content: quote: Originally posted by TheBerk: Papers have been struggling not so much due to lost revenue from subscriptions, but instead from lost advertising revenue. Credibility isn't what they are lacking, they are lacking the funds that sites such as Craigs List have impacted. Pay $500 or more to post a car ad in the paper or pay $0 for Craigs List. And even bigger issue is that during the newpaper "consolidation" period most of the newspaper ended up with a LOT of debt. Groups borrowed money to buy the paper and then other groups borrowed even more money to buy them again, etc. Many of the "failing" newspapers would be profitable if they did not have to pay the interest much less the principle on the loans used to churn ownership. IMO the ONLY people that usually profit from most mergers and acquistions are the lawyers, the Wall street brokers and the banks. This message has been edited. Last edited by: rayld2, Wed 25 March 2009 07:08 PM
